title: Witches' Sabbath (The Great He-Goat)
summary: Witches' Sabbath or The Great He-Goat (Spanish: Aquelarre or El gran cabr√≥n[1]) are names given to an oil mural by the Spanish artist Francisco Goya, completed sometime between 1821 and 1823. It explores themes of violence, intimidation, aging and death.[2] Satan hulks, in the form of a goat, in moonlit silhouette over a coven of terrified witches.[3] Goya was then around 75 years old, living alone and suffering from acute mental and physical distress.
